comments.commentBody: Well, duh - I didn't understand the theme until after I finished the puzzle successfully and read Jim's explanation.  How clever!  Clearly the product of a brilliant mind.
How come all of the entries are Anonymous?  What I was trying to say as "Anonymous #6" above was expressed better by "Anonymous #7".

Stu,

You've been just fantastic to read the past few years. Gonna miss your posts. Best of luck.

Good luck Stu. Sorry to see you go. I'll try to keep up with you at Sports Illustrated but no promises.

I think you're right on about the quality of the readers' comments matched with your particular passion and knowledge of the game. Come to think of it the NYT and sports coverage makes a happy marriage overall, with smart readers and lovable, low tech features like the slide shows for football games with only 10 or so photos compared to what I'm sure is a fancy pants, 316 photo gallery that whirls and twirls at Sports Illustrated.

I know you can bring your wonderful hockey head with you over to SI but I wonder if you can bring enough of the interesting readers along. I'm pretty old school, you know? Will the comments over there just be shouting matches about how my team is awesome and yours sucks all the time? Plus, I just went over there and my ancient computer can barely load a page at SI with all those bells and whistles and other moving parts they think the sports audience craves.

Is there a way to subscribe to your blog and have it jump up in my Gmail/google reader, or something like that? Just avoid navigating the site?

Sorry to sound so negative.

If I can get over the whole Halak / Price thing (notably with your hand holding!) then I can probably deal with a couple of visits a week to SI.
Stu, you will be missed by many who turn to the times. Hope the Times gets someone to try to fill your shows..

PS: Feel free to delete all this when you get the message... I would have put my comments in an email if I knew where to send it. And again, good luck on the new gig. Maybe you can change things for the better over there at a company that hasn't done a whole heck of a lot for the game of hockey, yet! I won't rule it out!
This seems weird in that I've traveled to Canada quite a bit for business, and the Discover Card is not recognized there, hmmm....
You've done such a great job with this blog, it's been a pleasure to follow hockey through your observations. Good luck with the new gig!

I don't mind the shootout, there are plenty of NHL games with so few scoring chances and clogged up neutral zone lay that it's a relief to finally see a skilled player come down alone on a great netminder.
Say it ain't so.  Seriously.  Your write-up, mash-up, musical blogs are epic.  Take a short sabbatical and hustle on back.

Hail & fare well.

You have a good shtick, fun and informative. Keep it going...
Good luck, Stu.
Stu, I look forward to your blog over at Sports Illustrated. Thanks for all the great coverage you've done for the Times, I always enjoy your posts. All the best!

I will absolutely be drifting over to SI for my hockey fixes, Stu. You're one of a kind. Please tell me that you'll continue illustrating your commentary with those great musical selections. Bon Voyage!!

Mouse Woman, please argue my point. Putting words in my mouth may feed your ego, but it does not address the point. Nowhere did I suggest that anyone be FORCED to do anything. Quite the opposite in fact. Amazon was indeed selling the horrible, forbidden book, until it yielded to pressure to pull it. In other words, Amazon was FORCED to pull the book by what amounts to little more than a mob. This is indeed the first step toward banning the book.

Just look at the hysteria in this discussion by people who have never laid eyes on the material. They have no idea what the book says. They go off the handle based entirely on the title and what they have been told secondhand. It is an online caricature of mob rule. This satisfies you as a self-proclaimed author? Perhaps YOUR prose should be banned without anyone reading it.

Banning and burning books isn't a "slippery slope". It's a yawning bottomless chasm any culture can fall into but few can emerge from. It is a starving predator waiting to be fed iconoclastic ideas, to destroy perceived but not real threats. Those who support it deserve what they get, but their kids and their more thoughtful neighbors do not.

Good for Google. Bad for the economy.....this is the beginning of the end of a lot of smaller retailers. Amazon will be OK given their volume but smaller retailers will have to surrender an ever greater share of their margin to Google to be heard (Google's recent salary increases are a great indication of above average margins). The shortsighted view is that it makes things more efficient just as we celebrated the consolidation of farms into fewer and fewer megacorporations. The long term view is that it destroys the ability for smaller firms to innovate and provide local differentiated services.

Google is a monopoly. Congratulations - it is the result of building a great product. But it is also the result of an FTC willing to allow certain mergers but the main reason is the great product AND increasing capital requirements to compete AND the natural network economics that come from a single brand and single destination. It should come as no surprise given we only have room in our minds for a single "yellow pages" versus many sources of directory information - Google has supplanted that in the online world. Granted this is a "soft" network effect but regardless - the result is a monopoly.

Just as we had to regulate AT&T (built through consolidation to achieve network effects).....we ultimately will have to regulate Google for the greater good of the economy. There will need to be a pure directory oriented search that is untainted by advertising.

"66.
J. Franz
Vancouver
November 12th, 2010
6:14 pm

It's absurd to think that absolutely no books can be banned."

And so it begins.

Yes, Facebook's 'Titan' email client could certainly be a game changer -

I have written about some of the great things we could expect from 'Titan', including a more social inbox - but also written about the 'cons' such as spam concerns stemming from facebook profile names and more:

http://jyml.me/9tqyny

Hope you enjoy,

Jay

Sorry, Facebook, but the LAST thing I want is you reading my email, seeing who I'm talking to, what I'm talking about, and having the ability to sell that information. I use Facebook when I feel I have no alternative to reach someone or keep in touch with someone. I absolutely won't let you snoop on my PRIVATE communications. The way you treat my publicly available private information is clue enough that I don't want to give you anything truly private.
Sure are a lot of snooty comments by NYTimes reader about a few light observations made by some Midwestern professors. A lot of overthinking and oversnooting...

I have studied the seismic data for this quadrant of our country and I suspect that facebook could achieve LEED's diamond status if they employ my breakthrough system of humming bird and goldfish biogenic cooling.

I want to give Facebook a trade sanction.
It is a complete parasite.
It prays upon the celebrity wanabee culture. It dupes the dull into using their service to contact friends and then sells the info to advertizers.
It mediates every single online service - including now NYTIMES BLOGS! Wait till they go public and every single dullard will have to pay everytime they do anything.

AND for what. They have no new technology. No new ideas. They are just the cocacola of the internet. The service who has somehow intermediated everything
and got everyone to use it.

And when Bloomberg says watch out, to the young who have no privacy, because this information about your life can be used against you, Zuckerberg invites him to facebook for saying a word against it.

WOW.

Maybe it will all implode. Really it adds no useful service. Lets hope.
Great -now I will never leave face "crack"
Meh..... Another email service.
What are they going to call it?  AOL?
